title: If we make the assumption that the asian market differs from the western market
body:
Largely due to the internet cafe phenomenon which instills the incentive for quick and short games, then can a game like league SUCCESSFULLY cater to the western and asian markets simaltaneously, or should league be split off into two entirely separate games for the two unique regions?

The western region having a balance philosophy that caters to long term strategic gameplay and the asian region have a balance philosophy catered to hectic action and doom fights that can end the game as early as 20 minutes.

Of course one major issue here would be continuity for the pro scene, but that begs the question as to, at least in the west, who gives a fuck about the pro scene if the game isn't fun?

It's no secret that the LCS is not particularly profitable at least in the west. Hell Scarra noted it's a loss leader. But a proper loss leader would attract people to the game while not alienating the existing playerbase.

This isn't about racism or nationality, it just seems evidently obvious that the western and asian regions have different gaming cultures, and that having a MOBA game trying to cater to both with the same balance philosophy is destined to fail for one of the regions (and currently it seems to be failing in the west in favor of asia since they have a larger playerbase).

Actually huge disagree on this. In NA markets, the predominant type of game that currently succeeds/has been routinely popular isn't strategy games but rather fast shooty-punchy games. It's why Fortnite and Overwatch (more so Fortnite) are the rising stars: Quick gameplay, fast paced twitchy-focus and more emphasis on quick games you can play. The equivalent to potato chips.

Internet cafe culture is a big deal, yes, but also bear in mind that games like Starcraft and Warcraft 3 are popular in both China and Korea. While it's easy to assume "Oh so they only like grand-scale strategy games", you have to remember that they have a major thing neither Fortnite nor Overwatch have: APM. I figure most people here know about APM considering the amount who go on about how much they love strategy games.

Anyways, with the way league has gone, APM is increasingly becoming more important with champs. It's certainly no starcraft but if you can't crank out like 30 APM when it matters in a teamfight, you're increasingly at a disadvantage. Which also coincides with the way boards often says they want to play: Slow moving champs with long CDs and more about slow-paced fights than heavy action fights.

It is an untenable solution, at best.

Thing is, I get both sides of the argument.  A large number of people want games to have more strategy, and a large number of people want shorter games.  Without doing some kind of actual cross-cultural survey, we have no idea which people precisely want which.  But, to use the dreaded term, the NA/EUW board are in a bit of an "echo chamber" simply because we do not have easy access to the prevalent opinions and ideas over in the Asian boards.  Or better put, because our boards don't have Google-translated, high-ranking posts from the Asian boards showing up in our NA/EUW board feeds, it isn't immediately obvious whether or not their opinions and ours for what LoL SHOULD be sync up.

I will say that if it is true that Riot is attempting to pander to the bigger market (the same way that another large company recently decided to do by making their next big Diablo game be mobile-based instead of PC) rather than the fans that GOT the company where it currently is, then that is beyond disappointing.  And if that is true, the only way to truly make Riot "hear" us isn't to just shout on the boards, but to show it with our wallets.  If you can't quit the game, then stop paying for skins and chromas at least.  When they see that they are losing their American sales market, they will do what they need to to gain us as players back.
